Knowledge Point: All elements in complex predicates, being part of the same clause, have the same mood\is{mood}, aspect\is{aspect} and polarity\is{polarity}, which is only marked on the last verb. In other words, there can only be one instance of the same mood, aspect or modality marking per clause. An example of shared mood with the plural imperative is given in~(\ref{exe:jieborar}), contrasted with a biclausal example in~(\ref{exe:jierarku}). An example with a complex predicate with predicate linker =i is given in~(\ref{exe:cimei}).
Content 1: \gll jie bo=\textbf{tar} | \gls get go=PL.IMP | \glt `Go get!'
Content 2: \gll jie=\textbf{tar} kuet=\textbf{tar} | \gls get=PL.IMP bring=PL.IMP | \glt `Get and bring!'

Knowledge Point: Also in non-contiguous predicates, mood, aspect and negation\is{negation} can only be expressed once. The \is{imperative}imperative marker in~(\ref{exe:yuatnar}) has scope over the entire predicate.
Content 1: \gll melelu wele yuwa=at narari=\textbf{te} | \gls sit vegetables PROX=OBJ slice=IMP | \glt `Sit and slice these vegetables!'

Knowledge Point: Shared aspect is illustrated here with progressive =teba. (\ref{exe:mggt}) is a complex predicate; (\ref{exe:mtggt}) contains two clauses with two predicates.
Content 1: \gll emumur mambara=\textbf{teba} garung∼garung=\textbf{teba} | \gls woman.PL stand={\glteba} chat∼PROG={\glteba} | \glt `The women are standing and [they] are chatting.'

Knowledge Point: \hspace*{-5pt}Finally, consider an example of a negated predicate, where the negator is marked on the second verb masara `move towards land' in~(\ref{exe:kurumaratnin}).
Content 1: \gll kalau mat \textbf{kuru} \textbf{masarat=nin=et} me pi barat=nin | \gls if 3SG.OBJ bring move_landwards=NEG=IRR TOP 1PL.INCL descend=NEG | \glt `If [they] don't bring him towards land, we don't go down.'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Subsection: Aspectual serialisation with koyet `to be finished'\is{aspect
Knowledge Point: Completive aspect, discussed in greater detail in~§\ref{sec:compl}, is made with help of the verb koyet `to be finished'. This is an independent verb, as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:kaitok}).
Content 1: \gll kai tok \textbf{koyet}=nin | \gls firewood yet finish=NEG | \glt `The firewood isn't finished yet.'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Subsection: Aspectual serialisation with koyet `to be finished'\is{aspect
Knowledge Point: Completive aspect is expressed with the construction Verb=i koyet, where =i is attached to a matrix verb of any kind. At the same time as being a complex predicate, this construction sequentially links the state, event or action in the first clause (which has to be completed) to a state, event or action in the next clause (which was started after completion of the first). Multiple monoclausal Verb=i koyet constructions may be strung together in this way. There are no restrictions on the first verb in the predicate. Both verbs in the predicate share the same arguments. (\ref{exe:ewunat}) shows the construction with a transitive verb in a narrative about making a canoe from a tree trunk. (\ref{exe:yoriko}) is taken from the end of that narrative, and shows the construction on an intransitive verb. Although it is uncommon, even the verb koyet `to be finished' may be used as the matrix verb in this construction, as in~(\ref{exe:koyeri}).
Content 1: \gll ewun=at potman=\textbf{i} \textbf{koyet} koi tim-un=at potma | \gls stem=OBJ cut=PLNK finish then tip-3POSS=OBJ cut | \glt `After cutting the stem, [I] cut its tips.'
Content 3: \gll koyet=\textbf{i} \textbf{koyet} kawarman | \gls finish=PLNK finish fold | \glt `After finishing, fold.'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Subsection: Aspectual serialisation with koyet `to be finished'\is{aspect
Knowledge Point: It is also possible, though not often employed, to make aspectual serialisation with two verbs before koyet `to be finished', as in~(\ref{exe:tena}). There is not enough data to determine the relationship between the two verbs marked with =i.
Content 1: \gll tena-un=at \textbf{tawaran=i} \textbf{manyor=i} \textbf{koyet} [...] | \gls keel-3POSS=OBJ chop=PLNK adjust=PLNK finish {\ob}...{\cb} | \glt `After chopping the keel straight, {\ob}...{\cb}.'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: (\ref{exe:tumkar}) illustrates a manner and directional verb, (\ref{exe:yalipa}) illustrates a manner and other motion verb, and~(\ref{exe:domanis}) shows the verb dorma `to pull out' with a directional verb.
Content 1: \gll setela ma yie=te an=a mat \textbf{yal=i} \textbf{parei∼pareir} | \gls after 3SG swim={\glte} 1SG=FOC 3SG.OBJ paddle=PLNK DISTR∼follow | \glt `After he [started] swimming I followed him paddling.'
Content 3: \gll ar-un wa-rip ye \textbf{dorman=i} \textbf{sara} | \gls stem-3POSS PROX-QLT or pull_out=PLNK ascend | \glt `Pull up [from the soil] a stem about as big as this.'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: These constructions are also very common with (y)ecie `to return', making complex centrifugal motion constructions, as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:danik}).
Content 1: \gll mat dan=i koyet se \textbf{ecien=i} \textbf{sara} | \gls 3SG.OBJ bury=PLNK finish IAM return=PLNK ascend | \glt `After burying him, [we] went back up.'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: As with aspectual serialisation (§\ref{sec:ikoyetsvc}), other complex predicates with predicate linker =i may also contain more than one verb. For example, in the manner + direction construction in~(\ref{exe:sirnag}), both manner verbs are marked with =i. Again, there is not enough data in the corpus to determine patterns in the (semantic) relationship between the verbs in the construction.
Content 1: \gll nasirang=i \textbf{mon∼mon=tun=i} \textbf{ran} | \gls pour=PLNK quick∼INTS=INTS=PLNK go | \glt `Go pour quickly.'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: This is also the case for NPs carrying similative postposition\is{postposition!similative} =kap, like ododa `gado-gado' (a dish) in~(\ref{exe:ododang}). Most colour terms end in -gap or -kap and are probably derived from nouns marked with similative =kap (§\ref{sec:sim}), but are treated as monomorphemic. They can also be inflected with =i and become part of a complex predicate, like baranggap `yellow' in~(\ref{exe:gawi}).
Content 1: \gll ododa=kap=i paruot=et | \gls gado_gado=SIM=PLNK make=IRR | \glt `Make [it] like gado-gado.'
Content 2: \gll wa me paden taikon \textbf{baranggap=i} \textbf{saran} | \gls PROX TOP pole one_side yellow=PLNK ascend | \glt `This one, a yellow pole goes down on one side.'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: Complex action and result predicates express an action in the first verb and a result in the second verb. Like resultative SVCs, §\ref{sec:ressvc}, they are rare. One natural spoken corpus example is~(\ref{exe:kakat}) with the verbs komain `to stab' and rua `to kill'. The object of the first verb is the subject of the second, such that the verbs in the construction do not share any arguments. In~(\ref{exe:dakcamp}), it is unclear exactly whether campur `to mix' is the result obtained by chopping two ingredients and the same time, or whether this should be read as two sequential events. The same conversation also contains the construction kawareni campur `grate mix'.
Content 1: \gll o mu se kaka=at \textbf{komain=i} \textbf{rua} | \gls INT 3PL IAM older_sibling=OBJ stab=PLNK kill | \glt `O, they killed the older brother (by stabbing).'
Content 2: \gll mier-gan=at paruo \textbf{dakdak=i} \textbf{campur} | \gls 3DU-all=OBJ make chop=PLNK mix | \glt `Mix both of them (by chopping).'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: A few other examples of action-result constructions with predicate linker =i were elicited with help of the cut and break clips \parencite{cutbreak2001}. Here, the resultative function of the constructions is clear. Consider~(\ref{exe:donsl}) and~(\ref{exe:pueip}).
Content 1: \gll ma karek=at \textbf{ramien=i} \textbf{meraraouk} | \gls 3SG string=OBJ pull=PLNK cause_to_snap | \glt `He causes the string to snap (by pulling it).'
Content 2: \gll pue=i parair | \gls hit=PLNK break | \glt `[Of a clip where a pot is smashed with a hammer:] break (by hitting).'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: %\textcite{unterladstetter2020} type: SREL resultative. V1 causing verb + V2 stative resultant verb. \ref{exe:donsl} does not conform.
Content 1: \gll ma karek=at \textbf{ramien=i} \textbf{meraraouk} | \gls 3SG string=OBJ pull=PLNK cause_to_snap | \glt `He causes the string to snap (by pulling it).'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: Reduplicated verbs marked with predicate linker =i occur in two contexts. The first is with reduplicated verbs that indicate durativity, followed by a construction with `until' which indicates the result of the action. The `until'-construction (with help of bo `to go') may (example~\ref{exe:kadok}) or may not (example~\ref{exe:kuarkuar}) be made in a separate clause. The second is in constructions with verbs that indicate durativity, but without an explicitly linked action (example~\ref{exe:rawiraw}), or with an implied `until'-construction (example~\ref{exe:komainik}). The verbs are typically lengthened (§\ref{sec:lenght}), as indicated in~(\ref{exe:rawiraw}).
Content 1: \gll kit-kadok=at \textbf{paruon=i} \textbf{paruon=i} bo koyet | \gls top-side=OBJ make=PLNK make=PLNK go finish | \glt `[We] made the top-side until [it was] finished.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{kuar=i} \textbf{kuar=i} ma se bo ruon | \gls cook=PLNK cook=PLNK 3SG IAM go cooked | \glt `Cooking, cooking, until it's cooked.'
Content 4: \gll mier se mu=at \textbf{komain=i} \textbf{komain=i} kon se tur | \gls 3DU IAM 3PL=OBJ stab=PLNK stab=PLNK one IAM fall | \glt `They stabbed and stabbed [until] one fell.'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: The `until'-constructions with bo `to go' illustrated in~(\ref{exe:kadok}) and~(\ref{exe:kuarkuar}) are also often found with distal manner \is{demonstrative!manner}demonstrative mindi and another verb, marked with predicate linker =i. The order is Verb=\textsc{plnk} + `like that' + `go' (example~\ref{exe:karuarr}). The construction can be elaborated with mendak, a demonstrative form probably derived from distal demonstrative me and clitic =tak `just', meaning `just like that' (§\ref{sec:distmann}). The `until'-construction then takes the form mendak=i + mindi + bo (example~\ref{exe:nasuis}). See §\ref{sec:distmann} for a discussion of the uses of the distal manner demonstrative mindi.
Content 1: \gll kit-kadok=at \textbf{paruon=i} \textbf{paruon=i} bo koyet | \gls top-side=OBJ make=PLNK make=PLNK go finish | \glt `[We] made the top-side until [it was] finished.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{kuar=i} \textbf{kuar=i} ma se bo ruon | \gls cook=PLNK cook=PLNK 3SG IAM go cooked | \glt `Cooking, cooking, until it's cooked.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{karuar=i} \textbf{mindi} \textbf{bo} kararak koi masan | \gls smoke_dry=PLNK like_that go dry then dry_in_sun | \glt `We dry [on a rack above the fire] until it's dry, then we dry in the sun.'
Content 4: \gll mu ko=melelu \textbf{mendak=i} \textbf{mindi} \textbf{bo} ma se nasuk=i saran | \gls 3PL APPL=sit just_like_that=PLNK like_that go 3SG IAM go_backwards=PLNK ascend | \glt `They sit on it until it [the haemorrhoids] has gone back up.'

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: Like with other types of complex predicates with predicate linker =i, we also find multiple verbs marked with =i in give-constructions. Consider~(\ref{exe:ningetmet}). As for the other types, there is not enough data to systematically analyse the relationship among the =i-marked verbs.
Content 1: Not found

Section: Complex predicates with predicate linker =i
Knowledge Point: The corpus contains three examples of complex predicates consisting of a noun inflected with predicate linker =i, followed by ra `to become'. An example with mun `lime' is given in~(\ref{exe:munira}). The other examples are with lempuang `island' and yar `stone'.
Content 1: \gll ma se mun=i ra | \gls 3SG IAM lime=PLNK become | \glt `He became a lime.'

Section: Complex predicates with dependent verbs\is{dependent verb
Knowledge Point: The independent verb kuet `to bring', illustrated in~(\ref{exe:mingkuet}), is only rarely combined with other verbs into a complex predicate, and is then always marked with predicate linker =i, as in~(\ref{exe:kueri}). It is also used in give-constructions, which have the zero morpheme `give', as in~(\ref{exe:kuerima}).
Content 1: \gll ka nene ming-un yuwa=at \textbf{kuet}=et | \gls 2SG grandmother oil-3POSS PROX=OBJ bring=IRR | \glt `You bring this oil of granny.'
Content 2: \gll bolon opa me tok \textbf{kuet=i} ran | \gls little {\glopa} TOP first bring=PLNK move | \glt `First bring over that little bit.'

Section: Complex predicates with dependent verbs\is{dependent verb
Knowledge Point: However, there is a dependent verb kuru `bring' which occurs as the first verb in complex predicates expressing transfer and motion. Kuru `bring' cannot be used independently, and never carries any morphology. The most common construction is with a directional verb (§\ref{sec:dir}), illustrated in~(\ref{exe:adiun}), or another verb expressing motion, such as luk `come' in~(\ref{exe:kurluk}).
Content 1: \gll ma se mara adik-un=at \textbf{kuru} \textbf{marua} | \gls 3SG IAM move_landwards younger_sibling-3POSS=OBJ bring move_seawards | \glt `He came towards land and [he] brought his brother towards sea.'
Content 2: \gll in se \textbf{kuru} \textbf{luk} et=at | \gls 1PL.EXCL IAM bring come canoe=OBJ | \glt `We brought [it] back, the canoe.'

Section: Complex predicates with dependent verbs\is{dependent verb
Knowledge Point: (\ref{exe:kwarin}) has three verbs: dependent verb kuru `bring', a directional verb ra `go' and the zero morpheme `give'.
Content 1: Not found

Section: Complex predicates with dependent verbs\is{dependent verb
Knowledge Point: (\ref{exe:sorg}) is similar, except that the recipient is a NP marked with benefactive =ki.
Content 1: Not found

Section: Complex predicates with dependent verbs\is{dependent verb
Knowledge Point: Otherwise, kuru `bring' is frequently combined with bo `go' and a location marked with the locative postposition =ko (indicating goal, example~\ref{exe:kuruboko}), with just a location marked with the locative (also indicating goal, as in~\ref{exe:kurulaut}), or with a lative and a motion verb (indicating source, example~\ref{exe:rumasak}). See §\ref{sec:svcloclat} for more complex predicates expressing source, goal or location.
Content 1: \gll ma \textbf{kuru} \textbf{bo} ror keit=\textbf{ko} | \gls 3SG bring go tree top=LOC | \glt `He brought [it] up to the tree.'
Content 2: \gll ma se an=at \textbf{kuru} laut=\textbf{ko} | \gls 3SG IAM 1SG=OBJ bring sea=LOC | \glt `She brought me to the sea.'
Content 3: \gll mu \textbf{kuru} rumasakit=\textbf{ka} \textbf{sara} | \gls 3PL bring hospital=LAT ascend | \glt `They brought [him] up to the hospital.'

Section: Complex predicates with dependent verbs\is{dependent verb
Knowledge Point: The dependent verb bon `bring' (possibly related to comitative postposition\is{postposition!comitative} =bon, §\ref{sec:comi}) occurs as the first verb in a complex predicate in combination with a motion verb like tiri `to run' (example~\ref{exe:borus}), rep `to get', marmar `to walk', bo `to go', bara `to descend' (example~\ref{exe:bonbara}) or sara `to ascend'.
Content 1: \gll Desi se nawas=te mengga \textbf{bon} \textbf{bara} | \gls Desi IAM carry={\glte} DIST.LAT bring descend | \glt `Desi came down carrying [the child], bringing it down from there.'

Section: Complex predicates with dependent verbs\is{dependent verb
Knowledge Point: The dependent verb toni `say; think; want' is used with the meaning `say; think' as the second verb in complex predicates in combination with verbs expressing speech, thought, or sensation, such as taruo `to say', as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:ttoni}). Other verbs accompanied by toni are gerket `to ask', narasa `to feel' and konawaruo `to forget'. More examples are given in §\ref{sec:speech}.
Content 1: Not found

Section: Complex predicates with dependent verbs\is{dependent verb
Knowledge Point: With the meaning `want' (discussed in detail in §\ref{sec:kin}), toni can be the first verb in a complex predicate, without any restriction on the semantics of the other verb. An example with bara `to descend' is given in~(\ref{exe:tonibara}).\footnote{It is unclear whether toni `want' can be used without volitional =kin (§\ref{sec:kin}). The corpus instances of toni followed by a verb that is not marked with =kin are ambiguous between the `want' and the `say; think' reading.}
Content 1: \gll lusi \textbf{toni} bara mat konggelem=kin | \gls eagle want descend 3SG.OBJ grab=VOL | \glt `The eagle wants to descend and grab him.'

Section: Complex predicates with dependent verbs\is{dependent verb
Knowledge Point: The dedicated negative verb eranun `cannot; to not be possible' is not a full verb: it cannot be inflected for mood and aspect. Moreover, it must always be preceded by another verb. This verb is nominalised with -un, such as karajang `to work' in~(\ref{exe:noobody}). For a further discussion of this construction, see §\ref{sec:lexicalneg}.
Content 1: Not found

Section: Complex source, goal and location predicates\is{location
Knowledge Point: The last complex locative predicate in the table, where a verb follows the locative, is a static locative construction. In~(\ref{exe:weleop}), the locative is combined with waruo `to wash', but the verb is also often a posture verb like maraouk `to put', mambara `to stand' or melelu `to sit' (cf. posture SVCs in~§\ref{sec:post}). %untst: position-to-position, no real complex predicate?
Content 1: Not found

Section: Complex source, goal and location predicates\is{location
Knowledge Point: Causative di= (§\ref{sec:di}) occurs in combination with directional verbs and locations in complex causative predicates. It attaches to the left edge of the complex predicate. It is also optionally employed in give-constructions (§\ref{sec:give}). (\ref{exe:bint}) is an example of a complex causative predicate with ra `to move (away); to become' (§\ref{sec:svcra}).
Content 1: \gll mendak embir-ne=ka sasul \textbf{di=ra} bintang ne=\textbf{ko} | \gls like_that bucket-inside=LAT spoon CAUS=move tub inside=LOC | \glt `So [I] spooned from the bucket into a tub.'

Section: Serial verb constructions\is{serial verb construction
Knowledge Point: Symmetrical SVCs consist of verbs from open verb classes, with no restrictions on the semantics of the verb. All components in a symmetrical SVC contribute equally to its meaning, so there is no `head' in the construction \parencite[][22]{aikhenvald2006}. Symmetrical SVCs express events consisting of two or more active verbs, given in sequential order (obeying the iconicity of order, \cites[288]{unterladstetter2020}[29]{staden2008}). They share their arguments. (\ref{exe:jieborar}) above is a symmetrical SVC. Additional examples are provided in~(\ref{exe:potmapar}) to~(\ref{exe:kajkow}). Note that in~(\ref{exe:perjiena}), the noun is incorporated into the SVC (see §\ref{sec:incorp} on noun incorporation)\is{noun incorporation}.
Content 1: \gll jie bo=\textbf{tar} | \gls get go=PL.IMP | \glt `Go get!'
Content 2: \gll pawan=at worman=i koyet in koi potman=i koyet timun=at \textbf{potma} \textbf{paruak} | \gls plank=OBJ cut_down=PLNK finish 1PL.EXCL then cut=PLNK finish tip=OBJ cut drop | \glt `After cutting down [trees for] planks, after cutting, [we] cut off the tips.'
Content 3: \gll usar=et mul-un=ka \textbf{kajien} \textbf{kowarman} | \gls erect=IRR side-3POSS=LAT pick fold | \glt `Erect [the basket], pick and fold [strips] from the side.'
Content 4: \gll in=a \textbf{per-jie} \textbf{na} | \gls 1PL.EXCL=FOC water-get consume | \glt `We fetched water and drank.'

Section: Serial verb constructions\is{serial verb construction
Knowledge Point: When an unmarked directional verb (§\ref{sec:dir}) is in the first position of a complex predicate, the construction can be a SVC. Like the examples above, they are sequential actions with a shared subject. They can also be purposive, such as bara komet `come down to look' in~(\ref{exe:barakom}). If a directional verb in a complex predicate is preceded by a non-directional verb, this verb is always marked with =i (described in §\ref{sec:mvci}), and this construction is thus not a SVC. (\ref{exe:marabara}) and~(\ref{exe:ranmina}) show SVCs of two directional verbs. (\ref{exe:ragerket}), finally, shows a SVC with shared subject, separated by the object of the second verb.
Content 1: \gll ma \textbf{bara} \textbf{komet} | \gls 3SG descend look | \glt `He came down to look.'
Content 2: \gll mengga koi mara \textbf{masara} \textbf{bara} | \gls DIST.LAT then move_landwards move_landwards descend | \glt `Then go inland from there, descend inland.'
Content 3: \gll pi konenen=i koi \textbf{ran} \textbf{mia=nin} | \gls 1PL.EXCL remember=PLNK then go come=NEG | \glt `We don't [have to] remember to come and go anymore.'

Section: Serial verb constructions\is{serial verb construction
Knowledge Point: Second, bo `to go' occurs in SVCs with stative intransitive verbs in change-of-state serialisation. Like in purposive motion serialisation, bo `to go' needs to be the first verb in the construction. Consider~(\ref{exe:borei}) and~(\ref{exe:eiririr}).
Content 1: \gll sontum \textbf{bo} \textbf{reidak} mindi | \gls person go many like_that | \glt `We became many people, like that.'
Content 2: \gll bungkus eir∼eir-i kahetma gelas \textbf{bo} \textbf{mikon} | \gls sachet two∼DISTR-OBJQNT open glass go full | \glt `Open two sachets each, until the glass is full.'

Section: Serial verb constructions\is{serial verb construction
Knowledge Point: Purposive motion serialisation can also be achieved with the directional verb ra `to move (along a path); to become' as V1. It is less generic than bo `to go', described above, in that it specifies the path of motion in combination with the other verb. This is also evident from its use as the antonym of mia `to come' (as in~\ref{exe:ranmina} above). In~(\ref{exe:mast}), the use of ra refers to the path from a floating fish cage to a boat. In~(\ref{exe:kulp}), the path from the speaker to the fire is indicated by ra. (\ref{exe:pasaromat}) is made with ra and the zero morpheme `give', to indicate the path between the giver and the recipient.
Content 1: \gll pi konenen=i koi \textbf{ran} \textbf{mia=nin} | \gls 1PL.EXCL remember=PLNK then go come=NEG | \glt `We don't [have to] remember to come and go anymore.'
Content 2: \gll Mas toni eh pi tiri \textbf{ra} \textbf{komet=et} | \gls Mas say hey 1PL.INCL sail move look=IRR | \glt `Mas said: ``Hey, let's sail out to look.'''
Content 3: \gll im=at [...] walawala=i din-neko kulpanggat=bon \textbf{ra} \textbf{sair} | \gls banana=OBJ {} throw=PLNK fire-inside triggerfish=COM move bake | \glt `[I] threw the bananas in the fire, baked [them] with the triggerfish.'

Section: Serial verb constructions\is{serial verb construction
Knowledge Point: Other examples are~(\ref{exe:ramin}) and~(\ref{exe:ragerket}) above. Ra `to move' is also used as the second verb in constructions with dependent verb kuru `to bring' (§\ref{sec:mvckuru}, example~\ref{exe:kwarin}), as the second verb in complex predicates linked by predicate linker =i (§\ref{sec:mvci}, example~\ref{exe:sirnag}), and in causative constructions (§\ref{sec:svcdi}, example~\ref{exe:bint}).
Content 1: \gll ka-mun mindi rami=in mena ma \textbf{watko} | \gls 2SG-PROH like_that pull=PROH otherwise 3SG PROX.LOC | \glt `Don't you pull like that, otherwise it will be here.'
Content 4: \gll nasirang=i \textbf{mon∼mon=tun=i} \textbf{ran} | \gls pour=PLNK quick∼INTS=INTS=PLNK go | \glt `Go pour quickly.'
Content 5: \gll mendak embir-ne=ka sasul \textbf{di=ra} bintang ne=\textbf{ko} | \gls like_that bucket-inside=LAT spoon CAUS=move tub inside=LOC | \glt `So [I] spooned from the bucket into a tub.'

Section: Serial verb constructions\is{serial verb construction
Knowledge Point: SVCs with melelu `to sit' and mambara `to stand' (introduced in examples~\ref{exe:mggt} and~\ref{exe:mtggt} above) can tentatively be grouped as posture SVCs. The first verb in the construction is the posture verb, and the second is a transitive or intransitive verb expressing some kind of activity. The verbs share the same subject.
Content 1: \gll emumur mambara=\textbf{teba} garung∼garung=\textbf{teba} | \gls woman.PL stand={\glteba} chat∼PROG={\glteba} | \glt `The women are standing and [they] are chatting.'

Section: Serial verb constructions\is{serial verb construction
Knowledge Point: Causative constructions are usually made with one of the proclitics di=, na= or ma= (§\ref{sec:caus}), but may also be made help of paruo `to make; to do' as the first verb in a complex predicate. It is often combined with stative intransitive verbs like samsik `thin' (example~\ref{exe:caussam}), but can also be combined with the \is{reciprocal}reciprocal verb naubes(bes) `to have a good relationship' (from reciprocal nau= and bes `good') to form the meaning `to make up' (after a fight).
Content 1: \gll manyor=i koyet ma yorsik an koi desil=i \textbf{paruo} \textbf{samsik} | \gls adjust=PLNK finish 3SG straight 1SG then plane=PLNK make thin | \glt `After adjusting it's straight and then I plane it to make it thin.'
